level.heading: REQUIREMENTS FOR NONPROFIT CORPORATIONS FORMED BY SPECIAL ACT OF CONGRESS (§7-705)

level.text: This section applies to nonprofit corporations formed in the District of Columbia by a special act of Congress, except to the extent that a requirement of this section is in irreconcilable conflict with a provision of the special act of Congress.

A nonprofit corporation described in § 705.1 that elects to become subject to Chapter 4 (Nonprofit Corporations) of the Act (D.C. Official Code § 29-401 et seq. (2011 Repl.) before January 1, 2014, shall file with the Superintendent:
A copy of the corporation’s congressional charter and any amendments thereto;
A copy of a resolution adopted by the corporation electing to be subject to the Act; and
A copy of the corporation’s articles of incorporation, if any.
A nonprofit corporation that makes an election under § 705.2 shall:
File a biennial report with the Superintendent by April 1, 2014; and
File subsequent biennial reports every two (2) years following the first April 1 filing.

A nonprofit corporation described in § 705.1 that does not make an election to become subject to Chapter 4 (Nonprofit Corporations) of the Act (D.C. Official Code § 29-401 et seq. (2011 Repl.) shall file with the Superintendent, no later than January 1, 2014, a statement containing the following:
The corporation’s name;
The corporation’s date of formation;
The name and address of at least one (1) governor of the corporation;
The name and address of the registered agent of the corporation; and
A copy of the corporation’s congressional charter and any amendments thereto.
A nonprofit corporation described in § 705.4 shall:
File a biennial report by April 1, 2014;
File subsequent biennial reports every two (2) years following the first April 1 filing; and
Maintain a registered agent pursuant to D.C. Official Code § 29-104.04 (2011 Repl.).

If a nonprofit corporation described in § 705.1 fails to file a timely biennial report or fails to maintain a registered agent, as required by § 705.5, the Superintendent may administratively dissolve the corporation.

A nonprofit corporation described in § 705.6 that is administratively dissolved may apply for reinstatement subject to the requirements of D.C. Official Code § 29-106.03 (2011 Repl.); provided, that the nonprofit corporation files the documents required by § 705.2 and the biennial report required by § 705.3(a).

level.heading: SOURCE
level.text: Final Rulemaking published at 60 DCR 13139 (September 20, 2013).
